bill_title: Permanently Preserving America’s Investment in Manufacturing Act
article_content:
# New Bill Aims to Permanently Support American Manufacturing Through Taxation

**Washington D.C.** – Legislation titled "Permanently Preserving America’s Investment in Manufacturing Act" is currently undergoing initial review within the House of Representatives, according to data released today. The bill, which focuses on taxation measures intended to bolster domestic manufacturing, was referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means as of October 21, 2025.

Sponsored by Representative Joseph D. Morelle (D-NY-25), the bill has garnered support from eleven cosponsors. Notably, Representative Morelle himself is a member of the House Committee on Ways and Means, the committee to which it was referred.

As of this reporting, no hearings have been scheduled for the bill. The most recent action recorded for the legislation is its referral to the Ways and Means Committee, marking an early stage in its legislative process.  Currently, there has been no indication of any proposed amendments to the text of the bill. 

Further updates on the "Permanently Preserving America’s Investment in Manufacturing Act" will be provided as they become available from the House of Representatives.

bill_title: Nuclear Waste Task Force Act of 2021
article_content:
# Bill Aims to Tackle Nuclear Waste Issues, Referred to Energy Subcommittee

**Washington D.C.** – Legislation aimed at addressing the challenges surrounding nuclear waste disposal has been introduced in Congress and referred to a key subcommittee for review. The bill, officially titled the “Nuclear Waste Task Force Act of 2021” (H.R. 5401), is sponsored by Representative Mike Levin (D-CA-49).

As of today, the bill has been referred to the Subcommittee on Energy within the House of Representatives.  While Rep. Levin is the primary sponsor and has a cosponsor, he is not currently listed as a member of that specific subcommittee. 

Currently, there’s no publicly available information regarding any hearings or discussions surrounding H.R. 5401. The most recent recorded action for the bill was its referral to the Subcommittee on Energy.  Furthermore, details about potential amendments to the legislation are not yet accessible in the provided data.  Four total actions have been documented for the bill thus far, all centered around its referral process.

The specific goals and proposed solutions within the “Nuclear Waste Task Force Act of 2021” remain under review by the Subcommittee on Energy.

bill_title: Middle Class Borrower Protection Act of 2023
article_content:
# Senate Introduces Bill Aimed at Protecting Student Borrowers

**Washington D.C.** – Senator Mike Braun (R-IN) has introduced the “Middle Class Borrower Protection Act of 2023,” aiming to provide protections for student loan borrowers, according to information released on July 13, 2023. As of that date, the bill was referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs in the Senate.

The legislation falls under the Finance and Financial Sector policy area.  Senator Braun is the sole sponsor of the bill, with fifteen other senators joining him as cosponsors, including himself from Indiana. Notably, Senator Braun serves as a member of the committee to which the bill has been referred. 

Currently, the bill’s progress within the committee remains at a preliminary stage.  Public records show it underwent “Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs,” signifying its initial review process.  To date, no hearings have been scheduled regarding the legislation, nor has any information been released concerning proposed amendments. Further action and debate will be required before the bill can move forward in the legislative process.

bill_title: Fighting Homelessness Through Services and Housing Act
article_content:
# Senate Bill Aims to Tackle Homelessness with Comprehensive Services and Housing Plan

**Washington D.C.** –  A new piece of legislation, titled “Fighting Homelessness Through Services and Housing Act,” has been introduced in the U.S. Senate and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions. Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) is sponsoring the bill aimed at addressing the complex issue of homelessness across the country.

As of today, the bill has undergone a second reading and has been formally referred to the committee for review.  Five other senators have cosponsored the measure alongside Sen. Feinstein. However, information regarding whether these cosponsors currently serve on the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions remains unavailable based on the current data.

Currently, the bill is awaiting further action within the committee. To date, no hearings have been scheduled or any amendments proposed. The last recorded activity was a second reading followed by referral to the designated committee.  The legislation has not yet proceeded to a vote and no details are available regarding its potential future developments.

bill_title: Bank Merger Review Modernization Act of 2021
article_content:
# Bill Aims to Modernize Bank Merger Review Process

**Washington D.C.** – Senate Bill 2882, officially titled the “Bank Merger Review Modernization Act of 2021,” is currently under review by the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs following its second reading in the Senate. The bill was introduced by Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA).

As of October 22, 2025, the legislation remains within the committee stage, where it will be examined for potential revisions and further consideration.  The “actions” section detailing the bill’s progress indicates that it has been "Read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs."

Currently, no information is available regarding cosponsors, members serving on committees beyond the Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs panel, or whether any hearings have taken place.  Furthermore, there are no records indicating any amendments proposed for the bill’s consideration at this time. 

Because it has only been referred to committee, the current stage of the bill does not permit an assessment of its potential bipartisan support or partisan leanings. The Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs will now determine whether to move forward with further action on Senate Bill 2882.

# Senate Bill 499: "Debbie Smith Act of 2023" Awaits Consideration

**Washington D.C.** – Senate Bill 499, officially titled the “Debbie Smith Act of 2023,” remains stalled in the Senate as of November 6, 2023, where it is currently “Held at the desk.” Introduced on February 16, 2023, the bill falls under the policy area of “Crime and Law Enforcement” and has received ten recorded actions.

Currently, the legislation is being reviewed by a single committee within the Senate.  Senator John Cornyn (R-TX) serves as a sponsor for the bill, alongside sixteen other cosponsors, including himself. While listed as a cosponsor, the bill does not currently assign any specific committee assignments to these senators. 

As of today, there has been one amendment proposed for Senate Bill 499. Details regarding this amendment can be found at https://api.congress.gov/v3/bill/118/s/499/amendments.  However, the publicly available data does not provide information about the proposer or specifics of the amendment's content.

The most recent action recorded for the bill was “Held at the desk,” indicating it is awaiting further consideration by the Senate. Information regarding whether this action represents a party-line vote or reflects bipartisan support is currently unavailable.  Further updates on the bill’s progress are expected as it moves through the legislative process.

bill_title: A resolution supporting the nearly 150,000 United Auto Workers currently negotiating collective bargaining agreements with the "Big Three" automakers.
article_content:
# Senate Resolution 412 Aims to Aid UAW Negotiators

**Washington, D.C.** – Senate Resolution 412 has been referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, aiming to provide support for nearly 150,000 United Auto Workers (UAW) members currently engaged in collective bargaining negotiations with major automakers. As of October 18, 2023, the bill's progress has been limited to this referral action.

The resolution garnered significant bipartisan backing, with thirty-three senators co-sponsoring it, including Senator Bernard Sanders (I-VT). However, Senator Sanders is not currently a member of the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions where the bill will now be reviewed. 

To date, no hearings or proposed amendments have been recorded regarding Senate Resolution 412. The sole action documented to this point was its referral to the committee on October 18th, 2023.  Details surrounding the vote on the referral are currently unavailable based on the provided information; only the act of referral has been tracked.  The bill's future trajectory remains uncertain pending further consideration by the relevant committee.

bill_title: Expressing support for the designation of May 5, 2023, as the "National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls".
article_content:
# House Resolution Aims to Recognize Missing & Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls

**Washington D.C.** – A House Resolution (HRES 353) seeking to designate May 5th as “National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls” is currently undergoing review within the U.S. Congress. As of November 15, 2024, the bill has been referred to the Subcommittee on Indian and Insular Affairs and is in its initial stages of consideration.

Rep. Dan Newhouse (R-WA-4) is a sponsor of HRES 353.  Currently, the resolution boasts 39 cosponsors, with an additional 39 having withdrawn their support. Notably, none of the listed cosponsors are members of the committees to which the bill has been assigned.

To date, no hearings have been scheduled on the legislation. The only recorded action regarding HRES 353 is its referral to the Subcommittee on Indian and Insular Affairs.  Furthermore, there is no data available indicating any proposed amendments to the bill at this time.

According to tracking information, five actions have been logged for HRES 353. The most recent action was the referral to the subcommittee, with details regarding the vote's partisan alignment not yet disclosed.  The resolution aims to raise awareness and support efforts surrounding the ongoing issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across the United States.

bill_title: To provide for a limitation on availability of funds for Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Injury Prevention and Control for fiscal year 2024.
article_content:
## Bill Aims to Limit CDC Funding, Referred to Health Subcommittee

**Washington D.C.** – Legislation proposing a funding limitation for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for fiscal year 2024 has been introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives. Designated as H.R. 1968, the bill is currently under review by the Subcommittee on Health.

Sponsored by Representative Andy Biggs (R-AZ-5), the measure seeks to restrict funding for the CDC. As of April 7, 2023, the bill has been officially referred to this subcommittee for consideration.

According to available information, five members have cosponsored H.R. 1968, with one cosponsor having subsequently withdrawn their support. However, details regarding the specific committee membership on the Subcommittee on Health remain undisclosed at this time. 

Currently, no information is available regarding any hearings or discussions related to the bill’s potential impact. The latest documented action indicates only that it was referred to the subcommittee – without further outlining any prior proceedings or debate. Furthermore, no amendments have been reported in connection with H.R. 1968.

# House Passes “Lower Energy Costs Act,” Senate Consideration Awaits

**Washington D.C.** – The House of Representatives passed the “Lower Energy Costs Act” (H.R. 1) on October 22, 2025, aiming to bolster American energy production and restore the nation’s leadership in the sector.  As of today's date, the bill is awaiting consideration by the Senate.

The legislation has undergone several technical corrections and amendments since its initial introduction.  According to data available, H.R. 1 is currently before five congressional committees. Notably, none of the 49 members who have cosponsored the bill are currently serving on those committees. 

Rep. Steve Scalise (LA-1) is the primary sponsor of the Lower Energy Costs Act. Recent actions taken by the Clerk authorized technical corrections to the bill, specifically focusing on punctuation and section adjustments.  This latest amendment, finalized as of October 22, 2025, did not involve a hearing or specific legislative findings.

Furthermore, thirty-seven amendments have been proposed for H.R. 1. Amendment 154, submitted by the House Manager, specifically addresses and modifies the bill’s budgetary effects, according to reports from the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).  The bill has already undergone one vote – on March 30, 2023 – authorizing technical corrections within its text. Information regarding whether that initial vote was partisan remains unavailable based on current data.
